required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Study to Define Optimal IGF-1 Monitoring in Children Treated With NutropinAq
clinical_study.official_title: Phase IIIB, International, Single Group, Open Study to Define an Optimal Monitoring of IGF-1 in Children Treated With NutropinAq, Using a Novel Capillary Blood Collection Method

brief_summary.textblock: The main purpose of this study is to establish an optimal monitoring regimen in NutropinAq treated children, using newly developed capillary blood spot IGF-1 measurement technology.

primary_outcome.measure: Insulin-Like Growth Factor I (IGF-I) Levels Measured Using the Timed Capillary Blood Spot Samples
primary_outcome.description: Fingertip capillary blood was collected using filter paper cards for the assay of capillary blood spot IGF-I in line with the monitoring recommendations of the Lawson Wilkins Paediatric Endocrine Society (LWPES) for treatment with recombinant GH therapy in children. Capillary IGF-I assays were performed by the patient at home one day per week during Weeks 21, 22 and 23 only (same week day). The samples were scheduled in the evening prior to the injection of NutropinAq and between 7:00 and 9:00 the following morning. An extended window from 6:00 to 12:00 was allowed for defining protocol deviations. The number of capillary blood spot IGF-I measurements and the optimal timing of samples to assess the IGF-I status of NutropinAq treated patients was assessed. IGF-I measurements for the morning and evening sampling are presented.

secondary_outcome.measure: Assessment of IGF-I Levels: Categorised by Weekly Timing (Weeks 21-23) and Daily Timing (Morning and Evening)
secondary_outcome.description: The influence of daily and weekly timing on the IGF-I value as measured using the capillary blood spot method was analysed. A 3-way analyses of variance (ANOVA) was performed with patient, day and daily timing as factors after appropriate transformation to obtain normally distributed parameters. The interaction day*time was tested and kept in the model only if p-value<0.1. Parameter estimates from the statistical model are presented as least squares means for the categories of daily timing (Morning and Evening) and weekly timing (Week 21, Week 22 and Week 23). The values reported for Week 21, 22, and 23 represent the average IGF-I levels from the morning and evening samples at each week. The values reported for Evening represent the Evening IGF-I levels averaged across Weeks 21, 22, and 23, and similarly for the Morning values.

secondary_outcome.measure: Assessment of IGF-I Levels: Categorised by Sex and Prepubertal Status
secondary_outcome.description: The influence of sex and prepubertal status on the IGF-I value as measured using the capillary blood spot method was analysed. Parameter estimates from the statistical model are presented as least squares means for the categories of sex (male and female) and prepubertal status (pubertal and prepubertal). The values reported represent average IGF-I levels as determined from the 6 measurements taken (i.e. morning and evening samples at Weeks 21, 22 and 23).

secondary_outcome.measure: Multivariate Linear Regression Analyses to Assess Factors Affecting the Variability of IGF-I Levels: Categorised by Disease Condition and Location
secondary_outcome.description: A multivariate linear regression analysis of factors on within-subject coefficient of variation (WCV) using a stepwise forward-backward elimination was used to determine the effect of individual factors on IGF-I values as measured using the capillary blood spot method (p=0.15 for a variable to enter and remain in the model). The WCV was computed from the series of 6 measurements (2 samplings in each of Weeks 21, 22 and 23). The influence of disease condition and country clusters on the IGF-I value were assessed. Country clusters: cluster 1: France; cluster 2: Spain, Greece, Romania and Italy; cluster 3: UK, Belgium, Czech Republic, Denmark, Germany, Slovakia, Austria and Finland ; cluster 4: Russia ; cluster 5: Ukraine. Parameter estimates from the statistical model presented as least squares means for categories of disease condition (GHD and TS) and location (Clusters 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5) are presented.

secondary_outcome.measure: Multivariate Linear Regression Analyses to Assess Factors Affecting the Variability of IGF-I Levels: Categorised by Time of Year, Calculated Age at Enrolment and Disease Condition
secondary_outcome.description: A multivariate linear regression analysis of factors on WCV using a stepwise forward-backward elimination was used to determine the effect of individual factors on IGF-I values as measured using the capillary blood spot method (p=0.15 for a variable to enter and remain in the model). The WCV was computed from the series of 6 measurements (2 samplings in each of Weeks 21, 22 and 23). The influence of the time of the year (1st, 2nd, 3rd and 4th quarters), calculated age at enrolment and disease condition on the IGF-I value were assessed. Parameter estimates from the statistical model are presented as least squares means for the categories of time of the year (1st, 2nd, 3rd and 4th quarters), calculated age at enrolment and disease condition (GHD and TS).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline at Week 24 in the IGF-I Levels as Measured by Capillary Blood Spot Method and Serum IGF-I Assay
secondary_outcome.description: 3 simultaneous IGF-I measurements were taken at Weeks 0 (baseline), 12 and 24 by serum and capillary assay to determine the precision profile of the capillary blood spot method versus the serum IGF-I assay. Change from baseline at Week 24 in the IGF-I measurements by capillary blood spot method and serum assay are presented.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline at Week 12 and Week 24 in Insulin-Like Growth Factor Binding Protein 3 (IGFBP3) Measurements
secondary_outcome.description: The LWPES recommends that treatment for any indication with recombinant GH therapy in children be accompanied by regular monitoring of IGF-I and IGFBP3 concentrations. IGFBP3 binds circulating IGF-I and serum samples were taken at Visit 1 (Week 0), Visit 2 (Week 12) and Visit 3 (Week 24) in order to measure IGFBP3. Change from baseline (Visit 1) at Visits 2 and 3 in IGFBP3 is presented.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline at Week 24 in the Auxological Parameter Height
secondary_outcome.description: The auxological parameter, height, was measured at Visit 1 (Baseline measurement), Visit 2 (Week 12) and Visit 3 (Week 24). Change from baseline in measured height at Visit 3 (Week 24) for the overall ITT population is presented.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline at Week 24 in the Auxological Parameter Calculated Height SDS
secondary_outcome.description: The auxological parameter, height, was measured at Visit 1 (Baseline measurement), Visit 2 (Week 12) and Visit 3 (Week 24). The French growth charts were used for the calculation of SDS parameters: the charts provide for each age range and sex a mean parameter and SD value, from which the SDS parameter can be derived assuming a normal distribution. For example: Height SDS = (height - reference mean height (age, sex)) / reference SD (age, sex). The SDS indicates the number of standard deviations away from the mean. A SDS of 0 is equal to the mean with negative numbers indicating values lower than the mean and positive values higher. A positive change in SDS indicates an improvement in growth, therefore, a favorable outcome. Change from baseline in the calculated height SDS at Visit 3 (Week 24) for the overall ITT population is presented.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline at Week 24 in the Auxological Parameter Weight
secondary_outcome.description: The auxological parameter, weight, was measured at Visit 1 (Baseline measurement), Visit 2 (Week 12) and Visit 3 (Week 24). Change from baseline in measured weight at Visit 3 (Week 24) for the overall ITT population is presented.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline at Week 24 in the Auxological Parameter Calculated Weight SDS
secondary_outcome.description: The auxological parameter, weight, was measured at Visit 1 (Baseline measurement), Visit 2 (Week 12) and Visit 3 (Week 24). The French growth charts were used for the calculation of SDS parameters: the charts provide for each age range and sex a mean parameter and SD value, from which the SDS parameter can be derived assuming a normal distribution. For example: Weight SDS = (weight - reference mean weight (age, sex)) / reference SD (age, sex). The SDS indicates the number of standard deviations away from the mean. A SDS of 0 is equal to the mean with negative numbers indicating values lower than the mean and positive values higher. A positive change in SDS indicates an improvement in weight, therefore, a favorable outcome. Change from baseline in the calculated weight SDS at Visit 3 (Week 24) for the overall ITT population is presented.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline at Week 24 in the Auxological Parameter Annualised Growth Velocity
secondary_outcome.description: The auxological parameter, annualised growth velocity, was measured at Visit 1 (Baseline measurement), Visit 2 (Week 12) and Visit 3 (Week 24). Change from baseline in the measured annualised growth velocity at Visit 3 (Week 24) for the overall ITT population is presented.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline at Week 24 in the Auxological Parameter Annualised Growth Velocity SDS
secondary_outcome.description: The auxological parameter, annualised growth velocity, was measured at Visit 1 (Baseline measurement), Visit 2 (Week 12) and Visit 3 (Week 24). The French growth charts were used for the calculation of SDS parameters: the charts provide for each age range and sex a mean parameter and SD value, from which the SDS parameter can be derived assuming a normal distribution. For example: Annualised GV SDS = (annualised GV - reference mean annualised GV (age, sex)) / reference SD (age, sex). The SDS indicates the number of standard deviations away from the mean. A SDS of 0 is equal to the mean with negative numbers indicating values lower than the mean and positive values higher. A positive change in SDS indicates an improvement in growth velocity, therefore, a favorable outcome. Change from baseline in the annualised growth velocity SDS at Visit 3 (Week 24) for the overall ITT population is presented.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Patients Rating the Overall Handling of the Administration Device, NutropinAq Pen, to Assess the Acceptability and Tolerance of NutropinAq and Its Pen
secondary_outcome.description: The acceptability was evaluated by a questionnaire at Month 5. The users (parents and/or child) of NutropinAq pen and compliance aid booklet were asked to describe and rate the pen, cartridge, compliance aid booklet and their ease of use. The percentage of patients responding to each category for the assessment of the overall handling of the NutropinAq pen are presented. The categories are: Very easy, Easy, Moderately difficult, Difficult, Very difficult and Missing.

secondary_outcome.measure: Posology of NutropinAq at Baseline (Visit 1) Summarised as Mean Dose
secondary_outcome.description: It was intended that the posology (mg/kg/day) of NutropinAq would remain constant throughout the study. The mean posology adopted at Visit 1 is presented.

secondary_outcome.measure: Extent of Exposure to NutropinAq Throughout the Study
secondary_outcome.description: The extent of treatment exposure throughout the study is presented as the mean number of daily injections performed.

arm_group.description: Patients received daily subcutaneous (s.c.) injections of NutropinAq 10 milligrams (mg)/2 milliliters (mL) for 6 months. The therapeutic daily doses administered were as follows: GHD patients: 0.025 - 0.035 mg/ kilogram (kg) bodyweight TS patients: up to 0.05 mg/kg bodyweight CRI patients: up to 0.05 mg/kg bodyweight Patients visited the study clinic for a baseline visit and for 2 other visits every 3 months (Weeks 12 and 24). Additional home assessments were made at Weeks 21, 22 and 23. The investigator determined the dose administered to each patient, and it was recommended to perform the injection in the evening.

intervention.description: Daily subcutaneous injections, 0,025 - 0,05 mg/kg/day for 6 months.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Children under 18 with growth failure associated with inadequate growth hormone secretion, or Turner syndrome or chronic renal insufficiency.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Children with closed epiphyses
- Children with active neoplasm
- Children with acute critical illness

facility.name: Il Università degli Studi di Napoli
Clinica Pediatrica, Universita Federico II di Napoli
Endocrinology Research Centre RAMS, Institute of Pediatric Endocrinology
Tushino Pediatric Hospital, RMAPE Department of Endocrinology for Childhood and Adolescent Age
Scientific-Research Institute of Endocrinology, Academy of Medical Science of Ukraine
Ukrainian Scientific practical Centre of Endocrine surgery, Endocrine Organs and Tissues Transplantation

participant_flow.recruitment_details: 251 children presenting growth failure associated with Growth Hormone Deficiency (GHD), Turner Syndrome (TS) or Chronic Renal Insufficiency (CRI) were screened (with informed consent) in 46 study centers across Europe. First patient enrolled: 7 June 2004; last subject completed: 22 July 2008
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Of the 251 children screened 3 did not receive study medication, 1 due to withdrawal of consent, 1 did not meet screening criteria for height and 1 was not included due to the investigator's decision.

group.title: NutropinAq 10 mg/2 ml (30 IU)
group.description: Patients received daily subcutaneous (s.c.) injections of NutropinAq 10 milligrams (mg)/ 2 milliliters (mL) for 6 months. The therapeutic daily doses administered were as follows: GHD patients: 0.025 – 0.035 mg/ kilogram (kg) bodyweight TS patients: up to 0.05 mg/kg bodyweight CRI patients: up to 0.05 mg/kg bodyweight Patients visited the study clinic for a baseline visit and for 2 other visits every 3 months (Weeks 12 and 24). Additional home assessments were made at Weeks 21, 22 and 23. The investigator determined the dose administered to each patient, and it was recommended to perform the injection in the evening.

baseline.population: The Intention-to-Treat (ITT) Population consisted of all treated patients (enrolled patients who received at least one injection of treatment) and who provided any follow-up data.

group.title: NutropinAq 10 mg/2 ml (30 IU)
group.description: Patients received daily s.c. injections of NutropinAq 10 mg/ 2 mL for 6 months. The therapeutic daily doses administered were as follows: GHD patients: 0.025 – 0.035 mg/kg bodyweight TS patients: up to 0.05 mg/kg bodyweight CRI patients: up to 0.05 mg/kg bodyweight Patients visited the study clinic for a baseline visit and for 2 other visits every 3 months (Weeks 12 and 24). Additional home assessments were made at Weeks 21, 22 and 23. The investigator determined the dose administered to each patient, and it was recommended to perform the injection in the evening.

measure.title: Age
Sex: Female, Male
Birth height
Birth weight
Duration of gestation
Genetic target height
measure.description: The genetic potential height, or target height was estimated using the adult height of each parent (i.e. genetic mother and father).

measure.title: Calculated genetic target height Standard Deviation Score (SDS)
measure.description: The genetic potential height, or target height was estimated as follows: Boys Target Height = [(mother height cm + father height cm)/2] + 6.5 cm. Girls Target Height = [(mother height cm + father height cm)/2] - 6.5 cm. The French growth charts were used for the calculation of standard deviation score (SDS) parameters: the charts provide for each age range and sex a mean parameter and standard deviation (SD) value, from which the SDS parameter can be derived assuming a normal distribution. For example: Height SDS = (height – reference mean height (age, sex)) / reference SD (age, sex).

measure.title: Duration of previous Growth Hormone (GH) treatment
measure.population: Data is presented for non-naïve patients only.

measure.title: Auxological Parameter - Height
Auxological Parameter - Calculated height SDS
Auxological Parameter - Weight
Auxological Parameter - Calculated weight SDS
Auxological Parameter - Annualised Growth Velocity (GV)
Auxological Parameter - Calculated annualised GV SDS

outcome.title: Insulin-Like Growth Factor I (IGF-I) Levels Measured Using the Timed Capillary Blood Spot Samples
outcome.description: Fingertip capillary blood was collected using filter paper cards for the assay of capillary blood spot IGF-I in line with the monitoring recommendations of the Lawson Wilkins Paediatric Endocrine Society (LWPES) for treatment with recombinant GH therapy in children. Capillary IGF-I assays were performed by the patient at home one day per week during Weeks 21, 22 and 23 only (same week day). The samples were scheduled in the evening prior to the injection of NutropinAq and between 7:00 and 9:00 the following morning. An extended window from 6:00 to 12:00 was allowed for defining protocol deviations. The number of capillary blood spot IGF-I measurements and the optimal timing of samples to assess the IGF-I status of NutropinAq treated patients was assessed. IGF-I measurements for the morning and evening sampling are presented.
outcome.population: The ITT Population consisted of all treated patients (enrolled patients who received at least one injection of treatment) and who provided any follow-up data. Only evaluable subjects with an assessment at the specified timepoint were included in each individual analysis.

group.title: NutropinAq 10 mg/2 ml (30 IU)
group.description: Patients received daily s.c. injections of NutropinAq 10 mg/ 2 mL for 6 months. The therapeutic daily doses administered were as follows: GHD patients: 0.025 – 0.035 mg/ kilogram kg bodyweight TS patients: up to 0.05 mg/kg bodyweight CRI patients: up to 0.05 mg/kg bodyweight Patients visited the study clinic for a baseline visit and for 2 other visits every 3 months (Weeks 12 and 24). Additional home assessments were made at Weeks 21, 22 and 23. The investigator determined the dose administered to each patient, and it was recommended to perform the injection in the evening.

measure.title: Insulin-Like Growth Factor I (IGF-I) Levels Measured Using the Timed Capillary Blood Spot Samples
measure.description: Fingertip capillary blood was collected using filter paper cards for the assay of capillary blood spot IGF-I in line with the monitoring recommendations of the Lawson Wilkins Paediatric Endocrine Society (LWPES) for treatment with recombinant GH therapy in children. Capillary IGF-I assays were performed by the patient at home one day per week during Weeks 21, 22 and 23 only (same week day). The samples were scheduled in the evening prior to the injection of NutropinAq and between 7:00 and 9:00 the following morning. An extended window from 6:00 to 12:00 was allowed for defining protocol deviations. The number of capillary blood spot IGF-I measurements and the optimal timing of samples to assess the IGF-I status of NutropinAq treated patients was assessed. IGF-I measurements for the morning and evening sampling are presented.
measure.population: The ITT Population consisted of all treated patients (enrolled patients who received at least one injection of treatment) and who provided any follow-up data. Only evaluable subjects with an assessment at the specified timepoint were included in each individual analysis.

analysis.groups_desc: An Intra-class Correlation Coefficient (ICC) for the evening series (defined as 12:00 to 24:00) was determined for the overall ITT population to confirm whether only one measurement would be sufficient to accurately represent the IGF-I measurement over Weeks 21, 22 and 23. The ICC expresses the relative magnitude of the 2 components of the total variability, i.e. the biological variability and random error, in a series of measurements on different patients.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: An one-way Analysis of Covariance (ANOVA) was used to calculate the between patient variation and within patient variation and then the ICC and its confidence limitations.
analysis.estimate_desc: An ICC ≥ 0.8 was considered satisfactory and indicative that a single sample would be representative of the overall IGF-I status.

analysis.groups_desc: An ICC for the morning series (defined as 06:00 to 12:00) was determined for the overall ITT population to confirm whether only one measurement would be sufficient to accurately represent the IGF-I measurement over Weeks 21, 22 and 23. The ICC expresses the relative magnitude of the 2 components of the total variability, i.e. the biological variability and random error, in a series of measurements on different patients.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: An one-way ANOVA was used to calculate the between patient variation and within patient variation and then the ICC and its confidence limitations.
analysis.estimate_desc: An ICC ≥ 0.8 was considered satisfactory and indicative that a single sample would be representative of the overall IGF-I status.

outcome.title: Assessment of IGF-I Levels: Categorised by Weekly Timing (Weeks 21-23) and Daily Timing (Morning and Evening)
outcome.description: The influence of daily and weekly timing on the IGF-I value as measured using the capillary blood spot method was analysed. A 3-way analyses of variance (ANOVA) was performed with patient, day and daily timing as factors after appropriate transformation to obtain normally distributed parameters. The interaction day*time was tested and kept in the model only if p-value<0.1. Parameter estimates from the statistical model are presented as least squares means for the categories of daily timing (Morning and Evening) and weekly timing (Week 21, Week 22 and Week 23). The values reported for Week 21, 22, and 23 represent the average IGF-I levels from the morning and evening samples at each week. The values reported for Evening represent the Evening IGF-I levels averaged across Weeks 21, 22, and 23, and similarly for the Morning values.
outcome.population: The ITT Population consisted of all treated patients (enrolled patients who received at least one injection of treatment) and who provided any follow-up data.

group.title: NutropinAq 10 mg/2 ml (30 IU)
group.description: Patients received daily s.c. injections of NutropinAq 10 mg/ 2 mL for 6 months. The therapeutic daily doses administered were as follows: GHD patients: 0.025 – 0.035 mg/kg bodyweight TS patients: up to 0.05 mg/kg bodyweight CRI patients: up to 0.05 mg/kg bodyweight Patients visited the study clinic for a baseline visit and for 2 other visits every 3 months (Weeks 12 and 24). Additional home assessments were made at Weeks 21, 22 and 23. The investigator determined the dose administered to each patient, and it was recommended to perform the injection in the evening.

measure.title: Assessment of IGF-I Levels: Categorised by Weekly Timing (Weeks 21-23) and Daily Timing (Morning and Evening)
measure.description: The influence of daily and weekly timing on the IGF-I value as measured using the capillary blood spot method was analysed. A 3-way analyses of variance (ANOVA) was performed with patient, day and daily timing as factors after appropriate transformation to obtain normally distributed parameters. The interaction day*time was tested and kept in the model only if p-value<0.1. Parameter estimates from the statistical model are presented as least squares means for the categories of daily timing (Morning and Evening) and weekly timing (Week 21, Week 22 and Week 23). The values reported for Week 21, 22, and 23 represent the average IGF-I levels from the morning and evening samples at each week. The values reported for Evening represent the Evening IGF-I levels averaged across Weeks 21, 22, and 23, and similarly for the Morning values.
measure.population: The ITT Population consisted of all treated patients (enrolled patients who received at least one injection of treatment) and who provided any follow-up data.

analysis.groups_desc: Analysis of the weekly timing effect (Week 21 versus Week 22 versus Week 23) on the IGF-I value as measured by capillary blood spot method.
analysis.other_analysis_desc: For the effect of the weekly timing on the IGF-I levels; F value = 1.79 and the significance probability value, PR>F = 0.1678.

analysis.groups_desc: Analysis of the daily timing effect (morning versus evening) on the IGF-I value as measured by capillary blood spot method.
analysis.other_analysis_desc: For the effect of the daily timing on the IGF-I levels; F value = 1.06 and the significance probability value, PR>F = 0.3035

outcome.title: Assessment of IGF-I Levels: Categorised by Sex and Prepubertal Status
outcome.description: The influence of sex and prepubertal status on the IGF-I value as measured using the capillary blood spot method was analysed. Parameter estimates from the statistical model are presented as least squares means for the categories of sex (male and female) and prepubertal status (pubertal and prepubertal). The values reported represent average IGF-I levels as determined from the 6 measurements taken (i.e. morning and evening samples at Weeks 21, 22 and 23).
outcome.population: The ITT Population consisted of all treated patients (enrolled patients who received at least one injection of treatment) and who provided any follow-up data.

group.title: NutropinAq 10 mg/2 ml (30 IU)
group.description: Patients received daily s.c. injections of NutropinAq 10 mg/ 2 mL for 6 months. The therapeutic daily doses administered were as follows: GHD patients: 0.025 – 0.035 mg/kg bodyweight TS patients: up to 0.05 mg/kg bodyweight CRI patients: up to 0.05 mg/kg bodyweight Patients visited the study clinic for a baseline visit and for 2 other visits every 3 months (Weeks 12 and 24). Additional home assessments were made at Weeks 21, 22 and 23. The investigator determined the dose administered to each patient, and it was recommended to perform the injection in the evening.

measure.title: Assessment of IGF-I Levels: Categorised by Sex and Prepubertal Status
measure.description: The influence of sex and prepubertal status on the IGF-I value as measured using the capillary blood spot method was analysed. Parameter estimates from the statistical model are presented as least squares means for the categories of sex (male and female) and prepubertal status (pubertal and prepubertal). The values reported represent average IGF-I levels as determined from the 6 measurements taken (i.e. morning and evening samples at Weeks 21, 22 and 23).
measure.population: The ITT Population consisted of all treated patients (enrolled patients who received at least one injection of treatment) and who provided any follow-up data.

analysis.groups_desc: Analysis of the effect of the patient's sex (male versus female) on the IGF-I value as measured by capillary blood spot method.
analysis.other_analysis_desc: For the effect of the patient's sex on the IGF-I levels; F value = 83.97 and the significance probability value, PR>F = <0.0001.

analysis.groups_desc: Analysis of the effect of the patient's pubertal status (pubertal versus prepubertal) on the IGF-I value as measured by capillary blood spot method.
analysis.other_analysis_desc: For the effect of the patient's pubertal status on the IGF-I levels; F value = 68.35 and the significance probability value, PR>F = <0.0001.

outcome.title: Multivariate Linear Regression Analyses to Assess Factors Affecting the Variability of IGF-I Levels: Categorised by Disease Condition and Location
outcome.description: A multivariate linear regression analysis of factors on within-subject coefficient of variation (WCV) using a stepwise forward-backward elimination was used to determine the effect of individual factors on IGF-I values as measured using the capillary blood spot method (p=0.15 for a variable to enter and remain in the model). The WCV was computed from the series of 6 measurements (2 samplings in each of Weeks 21, 22 and 23). The influence of disease condition and country clusters on the IGF-I value were assessed. Country clusters: cluster 1: France; cluster 2: Spain, Greece, Romania and Italy; cluster 3: UK, Belgium, Czech Republic, Denmark, Germany, Slovakia, Austria and Finland ; cluster 4: Russia ; cluster 5: Ukraine. Parameter estimates from the statistical model presented as least squares means for categories of disease condition (GHD and TS) and location (Clusters 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5) are presented.
outcome.population: The ITT Population consisted of all treated patients (enrolled patients who received at least one injection of treatment) and who provided any follow-up data. Only evaluable subjects within each of the individual subgroups are presented for each category. As there was only 1 patient with CRI, no analysis was performed for this disease condition.

group.title: NutropinAq 10 mg/2 ml (30 IU)
group.description: Patients received daily s.c. injections of NutropinAq 10 mg/ 2 mL for 6 months. The therapeutic daily doses administered were as follows: GHD patients: 0.025 – 0.035 mg/kg bodyweight TS patients: up to 0.05 mg/kg bodyweight CRI patients: up to 0.05 mg/kg bodyweight Patients visited the study clinic for a baseline visit and for 2 other visits every 3 months (Weeks 12 and 24). measure.title: Multivariate Linear Regression Analyses to Assess Factors Affecting the Variability of IGF-I Levels: Categorised by Disease Condition and Location
measure.description: A multivariate linear regression analysis of factors on within-subject coefficient of variation (WCV) using a stepwise forward-backward elimination was used to determine the effect of individual factors on IGF-I values as measured using the capillary blood spot method (p=0.15 for a variable to enter and remain in the model). The WCV was computed from the series of 6 measurements (2 samplings in each of Weeks 21, 22 and 23). The influence of disease condition and country clusters on the IGF-I value were assessed. Country clusters: cluster 1: France; cluster 2: Spain, Greece, Romania and Italy; cluster 3: UK, Belgium, Czech Republic, Denmark, Germany, Slovakia, Austria and Finland ; cluster 4: Russia ; cluster 5: Ukraine. Parameter estimates from the statistical model presented as least squares means for categories of disease condition (GHD and TS) and location (Clusters 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5) are presented.
measure.population: The ITT Population consisted of all treated patients (enrolled patients who received at least one injection of treatment) and who provided any follow-up data. Only evaluable subjects within each of the individual subgroups are presented for each category. As there was only 1 patient with CRI, no analysis was performed for this disease condition.

analysis.groups_desc: Analysis of the disease condition (GHD versus TS) on the IGF-I value as measured by capillary blood spot method.
analysis.other_analysis_desc: For the effect of the disease condition on the IGF-I levels; F value = 10.73 and the significance probability value, PR>F = 0.0012.

analysis.groups_desc: Analysis of the country cluster on the IGF-I value as measured by capillary blood spot method.
analysis.other_analysis_desc: For the effect of the country cluster on the IGF-I levels; F value = 2.20 and the significance probability value, PR>F = 0.0701.

outcome.title: Multivariate Linear Regression Analyses to Assess Factors Affecting the Variability of IGF-I Levels: Categorised by Time of Year, Calculated Age at Enrolment and Disease Condition
outcome.description: A multivariate linear regression analysis of factors on WCV using a stepwise forward-backward elimination was used to determine the effect of individual factors on IGF-I values as measured using the capillary blood spot method (p=0.15 for a variable to enter and remain in the model). The WCV was computed from the series of 6 measurements (2 samplings in each of Weeks 21, 22 and 23). The influence of the time of the year (1st, 2nd, 3rd and 4th quarters), calculated age at enrolment and disease condition on the IGF-I value were assessed. Parameter estimates from the statistical model are presented as least squares means for the categories of time of the year (1st, 2nd, 3rd and 4th quarters), calculated age at enrolment and disease condition (GHD and TS).
outcome.population: The Per Protocol Population consisted of all patients in the ITT Population for whom no major protocol violations/deviations occurred. Only evaluable subjects within each of the individual subgroups are presented for each category.

group.title: NutropinAq 10 mg/2 ml (30 IU)
group.description: Patients received daily s.c. injections of NutropinAq 10 mg/ 2 mL for 6 months. The WCV was computed from the series of 6 measurements (2 samplings in each of Weeks 21, 22 and 23). The influence of the time of the year (1st, 2nd, 3rd and 4th quarters), calculated age at enrolment and disease condition on the IGF-I value were assessed. Parameter estimates from the statistical model are presented as least squares means for the categories of time of the year (1st, 2nd, 3rd and 4th quarters), calculated age at enrolment and disease condition (GHD and TS).
measure.population: The Per Protocol Population consisted of all patients in the ITT Population for whom no major protocol violations/deviations occurred. Only evaluable subjects within each of the individual subgroups are presented for each category.

analysis.groups_desc: Analysis of the time of the year on the IGF-I value as measured by capillary blood spot method.
analysis.other_analysis_desc: For the effect of the time of the year on the IGF-I levels; F value = 3.65 and the significance probability value, PR>F = 0.0139.

analysis.groups_desc: Analysis of the effect of the calculated age at enrolment on the IGF-I value as measured by capillary blood spot method.
analysis.other_analysis_desc: For the effect of the calculated age at enrolment on the IGF-I levels; F value = 7.38 and the significance probability value, PR>F = 0.0073.

analysis.groups_desc: Analysis of the effect of the disease condition on the IGF-I value as measured by capillary blood spot method.
analysis.other_analysis_desc: For the effect of the disease condition on the IGF-I levels; F value = 3.86 and the significance probability value, PR>F = 0.0511

outcome.title: Change From Baseline at Week 24 in the IGF-I Levels as Measured by Capillary Blood Spot Method and Serum IGF-I Assay
outcome.description: 3 simultaneous IGF-I measurements were taken at Weeks 0 (baseline), 12 and 24 by serum and capillary assay to determine the precision profile of the capillary blood spot method versus the serum IGF-I assay. Change from baseline at Week 24 in the IGF-I measurements by capillary blood spot method and serum assay are presented.
outcome.population: The ITT Population consisted of all treated patients (enrolled patients who received at least one injection of treatment) and who provided any follow-up data. Evaluable subjects with data available at Week 24 are presented.

group.title: NutropinAq 10 mg/2 ml (30 IU)
group.description: Patients received daily s.c. injections of NutropinAq 10 mg/ 2 mL for 6 months. The therapeutic daily doses administered were as follows: GHD patients: 0.025 – 0.035 mg/kg bodyweight TS patients: up to 0.05 mg/kg bodyweight CRI patients: up to 0.05 mg/kg bodyweight Patients visited the study clinic for a baseline visit and for 2 other visits every 3 months (Weeks 12 and 24). Additional home assessments were made at Weeks 21, 22 and 23. The investigator determined the dose administered to each patient, and it was recommended to perform the injection in the evening.

measure.title: Change From Baseline at Week 24 in the IGF-I Levels as Measured by Capillary Blood Spot Method and Serum IGF-I Assay
measure.description: 3 simultaneous IGF-I measurements were taken at Weeks 0 (baseline), 12 and 24 by serum and capillary assay to determine the precision profile of the capillary blood spot method versus the serum IGF-I assay. Change from baseline at Week 24 in the IGF-I measurements by capillary blood spot method and serum assay are presented.
measure.population: The ITT Population consisted of all treated patients (enrolled patients who received at least one injection of treatment) and who provided any follow-up data. Evaluable subjects with data available at Week 24 are presented.

analysis.groups_desc: The Bland and Altman method was used to compare the results of each of the three simultaneous random capillary and serum measurements were compared. The difference between the capillary blood spot method and the serum IGF-I measurements is presented

outcome.title: Change From Baseline at Week 12 and Week 24 in Insulin-Like Growth Factor Binding Protein 3 (IGFBP3) Measurements
outcome.description: The LWPES recommends that treatment for any indication with recombinant GH therapy in children be accompanied by regular monitoring of IGF-I and IGFBP3 concentrations. IGFBP3 binds circulating IGF-I and serum samples were taken at Visit 1 (Week 0), Visit 2 (Week 12) and Visit 3 (Week 24) in order to measure IGFBP3. Change from baseline (Visit 1) at Visits 2 and 3 in IGFBP3 is presented.
outcome.population: The ITT Population consisted of all treated patients (enrolled patients who received at least one injection of treatment) and who provided any follow-up data. Evaluable subjects with data available at each timepoint are presented.

group.title: NutropinAq 10 mg/2 ml (30 IU)
group.description: Patients received daily s.c. injections of NutropinAq 10 mg/ 2 mL for 6 months. The therapeutic daily doses administered were as follows: GHD patients: 0.025 – 0.035 mg/kg bodyweight TS patients: up to 0.05 mg/kg bodyweight CRI patients: up to 0.05 mg/kg bodyweight Patients visited the study clinic for a baseline visit and for 2 other visits every 3 months (Weeks 12 and 24). Additional home assessments were made at Weeks 21, 22 and 23. The investigator determined the dose administered to each patient, and it was recommended to perform the injection in the evening.

measure.description: The LWPES recommends that treatment for any indication with recombinant GH therapy in children be accompanied by regular monitoring of IGF-I and IGFBP3 concentrations. outcome.title: Change From Baseline at Week 24 in the Auxological Parameter Height
outcome.description: The auxological parameter, height, was measured at Visit 1 (Baseline measurement), Visit 2 (Week 12) and Visit 3 (Week 24). Change from baseline in measured height at Visit 3 (Week 24) for the overall ITT population is presented.
outcome.population: The ITT Population consisted of all treated patients (enrolled patients who received at least one injection of treatment) and who provided any follow-up data.

group.description: Patients received daily s.c. injections of NutropinAq 10 mg/ 2 mL for 6 months. measure.title: Change From Baseline at Week 24 in the Auxological Parameter Height
measure.description: The auxological parameter, height, was measured at Visit 1 (Baseline measurement), Visit 2 (Week 12) and Visit 3 (Week 24). Change from baseline in measured height at Visit 3 (Week 24) for the overall ITT population is presented.
measure.population: The ITT Population consisted of all treated patients (enrolled patients who received at least one injection of treatment) and who provided any follow-up data.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline at Week 24 in the Auxological Parameter Calculated Height SDS
outcome.description: The auxological parameter, height, was measured at Visit 1 (Baseline measurement), Visit 2 (Week 12) and Visit 3 (Week 24). The French growth charts were used for the calculation of SDS parameters: the charts provide for each age range and sex a mean parameter and SD value, from which the SDS parameter can be derived assuming a normal distribution. For example: Height SDS = (height - reference mean height (age, sex)) / reference SD (age, sex). The SDS indicates the number of standard deviations away from the mean. A SDS of 0 is equal to the mean with negative numbers indicating values lower than the mean and positive values higher. A positive change in SDS indicates an improvement in growth, therefore, a favorable outcome. Change from baseline in the calculated height SDS at Visit 3 (Week 24) for the overall ITT population is presented.
outcome.population: The ITT Population consisted of all treated patients (enrolled patients who received at least one injection of treatment) and who provided any follow-up data.

A SDS of 0 is equal to the mean with negative numbers indicating values lower than the mean and positive values higher. outcome.description: The auxological parameter, weight, was measured at Visit 1 (Baseline measurement), Visit 2 (Week 12) and Visit 3 (Week 24). The French growth charts were used for the calculation of SDS parameters: the charts provide for each age range and sex a mean parameter and SD value, from which the SDS parameter can be derived assuming a normal distribution. For example: Weight SDS = (weight - reference mean weight (age, sex)) / reference SD (age, sex). The SDS indicates the number of standard deviations away from the mean. A SDS of 0 is equal to the mean with negative numbers indicating values lower than the mean and positive values higher. A positive change in SDS indicates an improvement in weight, therefore, a favorable outcome. A SDS of 0 is equal to the mean with negative numbers indicating values lower than the mean and positive values higher. A positive change in SDS indicates an improvement in weight, therefore, a favorable outcome. outcome.title: Change From Baseline at Week 24 in the Auxological Parameter Annualised Growth Velocity SDS
outcome.description: The auxological parameter, annualised growth velocity, was measured at Visit 1 (Baseline measurement), Visit 2 (Week 12) and Visit 3 (Week 24). The French growth charts were used for the calculation of SDS parameters: the charts provide for each age range and sex a mean parameter and SD value, from which the SDS parameter can be derived assuming a normal distribution. For example: Annualised GV SDS = (annualised GV - reference mean annualised GV (age, sex)) / reference SD (age, sex). The SDS indicates the number of standard deviations away from the mean. A SDS of 0 is equal to the mean with negative numbers indicating values lower than the mean and positive values higher. A positive change in SDS indicates an improvement in growth velocity, therefore, a favorable outcome. Change from baseline in the annualised growth velocity SDS at Visit 3 (Week 24) for the overall ITT population is presented.
outcome.population: The ITT Population consisted of all treated patients (enrolled patients who received at least one injection of treatment) and who provided any follow-up data.

A SDS of 0 is equal to the mean with negative numbers indicating values lower than the mean and positive values higher. outcome.title: Percentage of Patients Rating the Overall Handling of the Administration Device, NutropinAq Pen, to Assess the Acceptability and Tolerance of NutropinAq and Its Pen
outcome.description: The acceptability was evaluated by a questionnaire at Month 5. The users (parents and/or child) of NutropinAq pen and compliance aid booklet were asked to describe and rate the pen, cartridge, compliance aid booklet and their ease of use. The percentage of patients responding to each category for the assessment of the overall handling of the NutropinAq pen are presented. The categories are: Very easy, Easy, Moderately difficult, Difficult, Very difficult and Missing.
outcome.population: The ITT Population consisted of all treated patients (enrolled patients who received at least one injection of treatment) and who provided any follow-up data.

outcome.title: Posology of NutropinAq at Baseline (Visit 1) Summarised as Mean Dose
outcome.description: It was intended that the posology (mg/kg/day) of NutropinAq would remain constant throughout the study. The mean posology adopted at Visit 1 is presented.
outcome.population: The Safety Population consisted of all patients who received at least one injection of treatment.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There IS an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
